phrases.meaning: To be extremely happy or elated
phrases.example: When she got the promotion, she was on cloud nine for days.

phrases.english: To add fuel to the fire
phrases.meaning: To make a bad situation worse
phrases.example: His angry response only added fuel to the fire of the argument.

phrases.meaning: To be in trouble or facing difficulties
phrases.example: He's in hot water with his boss after missing the deadline.

phrases.meaning: To tease or joke with someone
phrases.example: I'm just pulling your leg! Of course I believe you.

phrases.english: To let the cat out of the bag
phrases.meaning: To reveal a secret accidentally
phrases.example: I accidentally let the cat out of the bag about the surprise party.

phrases.meaning: To understand the hidden or implied meaning
phrases.example: If you read between the lines, you'll see he's not happy with the decision.

phrases.english: To take something with a grain of salt
phrases.meaning: To be skeptical about something, not to believe it completely
phrases.example: Take his advice with a grain of salt - he tends to exaggerate.

phrases.meaning: To go to bed
phrases.example: I'm exhausted. I'm going to hit the sack early tonight.

phrases.meaning: To accept the consequences of one's actions
phrases.example: You made a mistake, and now you have to face the music.

phrases.english: To be in the same boat
phrases.meaning: To be in the same difficult situation as someone else
phrases.example: We're all in the same boat - none of us know what to do.

phrases.english: To bite off more than one can chew
phrases.meaning: To take on more responsibilities than one can handle
phrases.example: I think I bit off more than I can chew with this project.

phrases.meaning: To make people feel more comfortable in a social situation
phrases.example: I told a joke to break the ice at the meeting.

phrases.english: To take the bull by the horns
phrases.meaning: To confront a problem directly and decisively
phrases.example: It's time to take the bull by the horns and address this issue head-on.

phrases.meaning: To decide how to act based on the situation as it develops
phrases.example: We don't have a fixed plan. Let's just play it by ear.

phrases.meaning: To lose energy or momentum
phrases.example: The project started well, but we've run out of steam recently.

phrases.meaning: To correct a misunderstanding or false information
phrases.example: I need to set the record straight about what actually happened.

phrases.english: To keep someone at arm's length
phrases.meaning: To avoid becoming too close or friendly with someone
phrases.example: I keep him at arm's length because I don't trust him completely.

phrases.meaning: To agree with someone
phrases.example: We don't always see eye to eye, but we respect each other's opinions.

phrases.meaning: To survive a difficult period
phrases.example: The company managed to weather the storm during the economic crisis.

phrases.meaning: To join a popular trend or activity
phrases.example: Everyone is investing in cryptocurrency now, but I won't jump on the bandwagon.

phrases.english: To be a blessing in disguise
phrases.meaning: Something that seems bad but turns out to be good
phrases.example: Losing that job was a blessing in disguise - I found a much better one.

phrases.meaning: To take a risk and do something significant
phrases.example: After years of thinking about it, I finally took the plunge and started my own business.

phrases.meaning: To hope for good luck or success
phrases.example: I have my job interview tomorrow. Fingers crossed!

phrases.meaning: To lose one's skill or ability
phrases.example: I used to be good at tennis, but I've lost my touch.

phrases.meaning: To have enough money to cover basic expenses
phrases.example: It's difficult to make ends meet with such a low salary.

phrases.meaning: To fail spectacularly
phrases.example: The project went down in flames when the main investor pulled out.

phrases.english: To make a long story short
phrases.meaning: To summarize, to tell the main points briefly
phrases.example: To make a long story short, we decided to cancel the trip.

phrases.english: To put all one's eggs in one basket
phrases.meaning: To risk everything on a single opportunity
phrases.example: Don't put all your eggs in one basket - diversify your investments.

phrases.meaning: To not appreciate something because you assume it will always be available
phrases.example: We often take our health for granted until we lose it.

phrases.english: To go back to the drawing board
phrases.meaning: To start over, to rethink a plan from the beginning
phrases.example: The design was rejected, so we have to go back to the drawing board.

phrases.meaning: To start something immediately and effectively
phrases.example: The new manager hit the ground running and made immediate improvements.

phrases.meaning: To be extremely happy
phrases.example: She was over the moon when she found out she got the scholarship.

phrases.english: To read someone like a book
phrases.meaning: To understand someone's thoughts or feelings easily
phrases.example: I can read you like a book - I know you're nervous about the presentation.

phrases.meaning: To try every possible way to achieve something
phrases.example: We'll leave no stone unturned in our search for the truth.

phrases.meaning: To be in charge, to make the decisions
phrases.example: In this company, the CEO calls all the shots.

phrases.english: To bite the hand that feeds you
phrases.meaning: To harm or be ungrateful to someone who helps you
phrases.example: By criticizing his mentor publicly, he bit the hand that fed him.

phrases.meaning: To avoid attracting attention
phrases.example: After the scandal, he kept a low profile for months.

phrases.meaning: To change the rules or requirements during a process
phrases.example: They keep moving the goalposts, making it impossible to meet their expectations.

phrases.meaning: To improve one's performance or effort
phrases.example: If you want to compete at this level, you need to step up your game.

phrases.meaning: To be undecided, unable to choose between options
phrases.example: I'm on the fence about whether to accept the job offer or not.

phrases.meaning: I tend to think or believe something
phrases.example: I'm inclined to believe that the new policy will be effective.

phrases.meaning: I believe that, I think that
phrases.example: I'm of the opinion that we should wait before making a decision.

phrases.meaning: I believe that something is true
phrases.example: I'm under the impression that the meeting was cancelled.

phrases.meaning: I have been given information that makes me think something
phrases.example: I'm led to believe that the project will be completed on time.

phrases.meaning: I have been informed that
phrases.example: I'm given to understand that there will be changes to the schedule.

phrases.meaning: I feel I must say that
phrases.example: I'm bound to say that I disagree with this approach.

phrases.meaning: I feel I must mention that
phrases.example: I'm compelled to mention that this decision could have serious consequences.

phrases.english: I'm obliged to point out that
phrases.meaning: I feel I must point out that
phrases.example: I'm obliged to point out that we're running behind schedule.

phrases.meaning: I must conclude that
phrases.example: After reviewing all the evidence, I'm forced to conclude that we need a different approach.

phrases.meaning: I don't want to admit that, but I must
phrases.example: I'm reluctant to admit that I was wrong about this.

phrases.meaning: I'm uncertain about saying that
phrases.example: I'm hesitant to say that this will work, but it's worth trying.

phrases.meaning: I tend to think that
phrases.example: I'm prone to think that we're overcomplicating this issue.

phrases.meaning: I'm likely to believe that
phrases.example: I'm apt to believe that the situation will improve soon.

phrases.meaning: I'm likely to think that
phrases.example: I'm liable to think that we need more time to consider this properly.

phrases.meaning: I'm inclined to agree that
phrases.example: I'm disposed to agree that this is the best course of action.

phrases.meaning: I'm inclined to think that
phrases.example: I'm predisposed to think that this approach will be more effective.

phrases.english: I'm not in a position to
phrases.meaning: I'm not able to, I don't have the authority or ability to
phrases.example: I'm not in a position to make that decision without consulting my supervisor.

phrases.meaning: I'm not able to, I don't have the right to
phrases.example: I'm in no position to criticize others when I make mistakes too.

phrases.meaning: I'm able to, I have the authority or ability to
phrases.example: I'm in a position to offer you a better deal if you're interested.

phrases.meaning: I'm not allowed to, I don't have permission to
phrases.example: I'm not at liberty to discuss the details of the contract.

phrases.meaning: I'm allowed to, I have permission to
phrases.example: I'm at liberty to share this information with you now.

phrases.english: I'm not in the habit of
phrases.meaning: I don't usually do something
phrases.example: I'm not in the habit of making promises I can't keep.

phrases.meaning: I usually do something
phrases.example: I'm in the habit of reading before I go to sleep.

phrases.meaning: I'm not used to something
phrases.example: I'm not accustomed to working such long hours.

phrases.meaning: I'm used to something
phrases.example: I'm accustomed to dealing with difficult situations.

phrases.meaning: I don't know much about something
phrases.example: I'm not familiar with the new software system.

phrases.meaning: I know about something
phrases.example: I'm familiar with the procedures, so I can help you.

phrases.meaning: I don't know something or someone
phrases.example: I'm not acquainted with the details of the case.

phrases.meaning: I know something or someone
phrases.example: I'm acquainted with the manager, so I can introduce you.

phrases.meaning: I don't have knowledge or skill in something
phrases.example: I'm not versed in financial matters, so I'll need to consult an expert.

phrases.meaning: I have knowledge or skill in something
phrases.example: I'm well versed in international law, so I can help with this case.

phrases.meaning: I'm not skilled in something
phrases.example: I'm not proficient in Spanish, but I can understand basic conversations.

phrases.meaning: I'm skilled in something
phrases.example: I'm proficient in several programming languages.

phrases.meaning: I don't have the ability to do something
phrases.example: I'm not competent in handling such complex negotiations.

phrases.meaning: I have the ability to do something
phrases.example: I'm competent in managing large teams and complex projects.

phrases.meaning: I don't have the credentials or skills to do something
phrases.example: I'm not qualified to give medical advice, so please consult a doctor.

phrases.meaning: I have the credentials or skills to do something
phrases.example: I'm qualified to teach English as a second language.

phrases.meaning: I don't have permission to do something
phrases.example: I'm not authorized to approve expenses over a certain amount.

phrases.meaning: I have permission to do something
phrases.example: I'm authorized to sign contracts on behalf of the company.

phrases.meaning: I don't have the right to something
phrases.example: I'm not entitled to a refund because I used the product.

phrases.meaning: I have the right to something
phrases.example: I'm entitled to a break after working for four hours.

phrases.meaning: I'm not required to do something
phrases.example: I'm not obliged to attend the meeting, but I'll go anyway.

phrases.meaning: I'm required to do something
phrases.example: I'm obliged to report any safety violations to management.

phrases.meaning: I'm not required to do something
phrases.example: I'm not bound to accept the first offer, so I'll wait for better terms.

phrases.meaning: I'm required to do something
phrases.example: I'm bound by contract to complete this project by the end of the month.

phrases.meaning: I'm not dedicated to something
phrases.example: I'm not committed to this plan yet - I'm still considering alternatives.

phrases.meaning: I'm dedicated to something
phrases.example: I'm committed to improving the quality of our services.

phrases.meaning: I'm not devoted to something
phrases.example: I'm not dedicated to this approach - I think we should try something else.

phrases.meaning: I'm devoted to something
phrases.example: I'm dedicated to helping my team succeed.

phrases.meaning: I'm not committed to something
phrases.example: I'm not devoted to this idea - I'm open to other suggestions.

phrases.meaning: I'm committed to something
phrases.example: I'm devoted to my family and my work.

phrases.meaning: I'm not emotionally connected to something
phrases.example: I'm not attached to this plan - we can change it if needed.

phrases.meaning: I'm emotionally connected to something
phrases.example: I'm very attached to this old house - I've lived here for 20 years.

phrases.meaning: I don't prefer something
phrases.example: I'm not partial to spicy food - I prefer milder flavors.

phrases.meaning: I prefer something
phrases.example: I'm partial to Italian cuisine - it's my favorite.

phrases.meaning: I'm not easily influenced by something
phrases.example: I'm not susceptible to peer pressure - I make my own decisions.

phrases.meaning: I'm easily influenced by something
phrases.example: I'm susceptible to colds in the winter - I always get sick.

phrases.meaning: I'm not protected from something
phrases.example: I'm not immune to criticism - it still affects me sometimes.

phrases.meaning: I'm protected from something
phrases.example: I'm immune to his charm - I know what he's really like.

phrases.meaning: I'm not able to withstand something
phrases.example: I'm not resistant to change - I adapt quickly to new situations.

phrases.meaning: I'm able to withstand something
phrases.example: I'm resistant to stress - I can handle pressure well.

phrases.meaning: I'm not easily harmed by something
phrases.example: I'm not vulnerable to manipulation - I can see through people's motives.

phrases.meaning: I'm easily harmed by something
phrases.example: I'm vulnerable to flattery - I like to hear positive things about myself.

phrases.meaning: I don't tend to do something
phrases.example: I'm not prone to making hasty decisions - I think things through carefully.

phrases.meaning: I tend to do something
phrases.example: I'm prone to overthinking things - I analyze everything too much.

phrases.meaning: I don't tend to do something
phrases.example: I'm not inclined to trust people immediately - I need to know them first.

phrases.meaning: I tend to do something
phrases.example: I'm inclined to agree with your proposal - it sounds reasonable.

phrases.meaning: I'm not willing to do something
phrases.example: I'm not disposed to compromise on this issue - it's too important.

phrases.meaning: I'm willing to do something
phrases.example: I'm disposed to help you with this project if you need assistance.

phrases.meaning: I don't have a tendency to do something
phrases.example: I'm not predisposed to taking risks - I prefer a more cautious approach.
